title: TCS typically follows a two-stage selection process for hiring new recruits:
content:
1. Written Exam (National Qualifier Test - NQT):

This is the first hurdle and can be quite competitive.
The NQT is designed to assess a candidate's basic skills across various areas.
The test format may vary slightly depending on the specific role and location, but generally covers:
Verbal Ability (e.g., grammar, vocabulary)
Quantitative Ability (e.g., mathematics, data interpretation)
Reasoning Ability (e.g., logical thinking, problem-solving)
Programming Logic (e.g., understanding of algorithms, data structures)
Hands-on Coding (may involve writing code for simple problems)
2. Interview Rounds:

If you clear the NQT, you'll be called for interview rounds.
The number and type of interviews may vary depending on the role and seniority, but often involve:
Technical Interview: This deep dives into your technical knowledge based on your education, skills mentioned in your resume, and the specific job requirements. You may be asked questions on programming languages, databases, operating systems, computer networks, and Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) concepts. Be prepared to write code on paper or a whiteboard to demonstrate your problem-solving skills.
Managerial Round (or HR Round): This round assesses your overall suitability for the role and the company culture. It might involve questions about your previous projects, teamwork experience, communication skills, and behavioral questions.
Tips for Preparing for TCS Interviews:

Thoroughly understand the job description and tailor your preparation accordingly.
Brush up on your technical skills relevant to the position.
Practice writing code for common algorithms and data structures.
Prepare for behavioral and HR questions using the STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result).
Research TCS and be able to articulate why you want to work there.
By understanding the TCS interview pattern and preparing well, you can increase your chances of success in the recruitment process.

title: SDE Intern
content:
Problem: Design a URL Shortener

You are tasked with designing a URL shortening service similar to Bitly or TinyURL. Your service should take long URLs and generate short, unique aliases for them. When a user accesses the short URL, they should be redirected to the original long URL.

Implement the following functionalities:

shorten(longUrl): Given a long URL, return a short URL. The short URL should be unique and not easily guessable.
restore(shortUrl): Given a short URL, return the corresponding long URL. If the short URL doesn't exist or has expired, return an error message.
Your solution should minimize the length of the generated short URLs while ensuring they are unique across all URLs shortened by your service. Additionally, you should optimize for fast lookup and retrieval of long URLs from their corresponding short URLs.

You can assume the input URLs are valid and follow the format of a standard URL.

title: Microsoft | SWE Intern | Hyderabad, India
content:
Dear LeetCode Community,

I hope this post finds you well. I recently had the privilege of interviewing for a Software Engineering Intern position at Microsoft, and I wanted to share my experience and offer some insights for those who may be preparing for similar interviews.

**Interview Process Overview:**

* Resume Shortlisting: 
 The journey began with the resume shortlisting phase, where my qualifications were evaluated to proceed to the next stage.

* Coding Round (Online Assessment on Codility):
The second stage involved an online coding assessment on Codility, testing my coding skills and problem-solving abilities.

* Technical Interviews (Rounds 3 and 4):
The final rounds consisted of two technical interviews, each lasting around one hour and 1.5 hours, respectively.

* **Round 1:**

		Duration: Approximately 1 hour
		Content: Array (LeetCode Medium) and Tree BFS
		Additional Topics: Java basics and variations in the Tree question
* **Round 2:**

		Duration: Approximately 1.5 hours
		Content: 6-7 questions covering Trees, Trie, Stack (Hard), Array, and Kadane's Algorithm
		Difficulty: LeetCode Medium and Hard
		
**Verdict:**
Received my acceptance for the position of software engineer summer intern (8 weeks) and location is Hyderabad with a stipend of 1lac+ per month and a relocation bonus of 1lac.

**Interviewer Interaction:**
Both interviewers were friendly and supportive, creating a comfortable environment.
They encouraged questions, clarifications, and provided hints when requested.

**Tips and Tricks for Success:**
1. Keep your introduction concise and focused.
2. Seek clarification from the interviewer if any part of the question is unclear.
3. Don't hesitate to ask for hints if you find yourself stuck during problem-solving.
4. Take a minute or two to organize your thoughts before responding to a question.
5. If you're unsure about an answer, be honest and communicate that you don't know, rather than attempting to fabricate a response.
6. Avoid any attempts to cheat, as experienced interviewers can easily detect such behavior, leading to disqualification.

title: Salesforce vs Zomato
content:
Salesforce vs Zomato
Education: B.Tech from Tier 1
Exp: 2 years 7 months in Product Based Company

I got offers from Salesforce and Zomato

Salesforce SDE2:
* Base: 31.5L
* Performance Bonus: 10% of Base
* RSUs: ~56.5K USD, vested over 4 yrs (25% each year) (~12L per year)
* One time Relocation bonus: 1.5L (Not a reimbursement)
* Standard Salesforce Perks and Benefits. Iphone 14, Wellness reimbursement, Health insurance etc.

Zomato SDE2:
* Base: 33L
* Annual Bonus: 10L (at the end of year)
* Relocation 14 days stay + Reimbursements upto 1.5L
* Zomato doesn't offer any other perks/benefits as such

Any suggestions which is better? In terms of learning and growth opportunities, WLB.

title: ❗❗DSA and System Design enough for interviews?
content:
My background: Graduated from a Tier-3 College in 2021 and was laid off in September 2023 from a mid sized PBC. Got an offer in December 2023. Gave multiple interviews in between. 
​
I haven't really tried switching before being laid off but I was practicing DSA on leetcode. My Experience during the interviews were confusing. I have worked on a .Net tech stack and was trying to make a switch on the same tech stack. Interviewed with various companies. VMWare(LLD Reject), Amazon(DSA reject) and many more. But what surprised me was that none of the interviewers were really interested in knowing about my tech stack which I have worked on. After multiple interviews, I figured out DSA and System Design is the only constraint. I know if I have practiced DSA and System Design, it is easier to get through learning new technology but is it enough to make the switch. For Ex - If Someone is from java stack and want to switch to GoLang, learning DSA and System Design along with a good GoLang Project will get him through the position. Is it the norm in the market? 
​
I am asking just out of curiosity. Apologies if I am thinking the wrong way but I am just trying to understand the process?

Benefits: 15 paid vacation days + 10 paid sick leave days + 10 paid U.S. holidays + 2 paid personal days + yearly sports stipend of $800 to spend on sports stuff or free gym membership + 50% 401k/Roth match up to $9k/yr + covered health/dental/vision
Other details: Negotiated once, original offer did not have signing bonus. Was given a week to accept or decline the offer.
❗Please also tag your post with the company name and office location.
❗If you received your offer over 1 year ago, please refrain from posting it.

The title of the post should at least include the company and position, and ideally would follow this format:

Company Name | Position (level) | Location
For example, this could look like:

Amazon | SDE2 | Seattle
Google | Intern | Mountain View

title: Seeking Insights for SDE-3(Data Engineer) Role at Kotak Mahindra Bank
content:
Hello LC community,

I hope this message finds you well. I am reaching out to gather insights and advice regarding the interview process and compensation expectations for the SDE-3 - Data Enginner role at Kotak Mahindra Bank in Bangalore, India.

Here are some details about my profile:

Education: BTech from a Tier-3 college
Years of Experience: 8 years
**Current Role:** Senior Software Engineer - Big Data at a Unicorn Startup (current), Previous experience with a Popular Tech Giant
**Current Salary:** ~45 LPA fixed + 40L ESOP (4-year vesting)

**Upcoming Interview:** 
Cleared the first-round bar-raiser interview; the second round is scheduled for next week
Offer Details: Before the interview, Kotak Mahindra Bank communicated that the maximum they can offer is 50 LPA fixed + 5 LPA performance bonus, making it a total of 55 LPA for SDE-3. No stock bonus is mentioned, and the total compensation (Salary + Bonus + Stock) is estimated to be around 55 LPA.

**Negotiation Outcome:** Attempts to negotiate were met with the recruiter stating that the provided offer is the best they can offer before the interview.

I am seeking advice on **what to expect in the second round of the interview**, especially considering that the first round was conducted by a bar-raiser from a third-party and feedback was very positive. Additionally, given the provided offer details, I would appreciate any insights into whether this offer is competitive for the SDE-3 role at Kotak Mahindra Bank.

If anyone has experience with Kotak's data engineering interviews or has insights into the expected compensation for similar roles, your guidance would be highly valuable.

Thank you in advance for sharing your experiences and insights.

title: Seeking Advice on Career Path - MS in USA vs. Current Job Opportunity
content:
Hi everyone,

I find myself at a bit of a crossroads and would really appreciate some guidance from this community. Here's my situation:

**Background**:

Initially planned for MS in USA in 2025.
Recently secured a job in one of the FAANG level companies in India with a first-year CTC of 33 LPA.

**Profile:**
B.Tech in CSE from a Tier 2 college, 2022 grad.
8 CGPA, 1 international, and 1 national research paper.
1.7 YOE in a PBC.

**Dilemma:**
I am now torn between continuing with my original plan of pursuing MS in the USA or taking advantage of the current job opportunity in India. I would like to seek your valuable insights on the following options:

**1. Stick to the original plan of pursuing MS in the USA in 2025?
2. Defer MS to 2026?
3. Focus on securing onsite opportunities from my current FAANG job?**

I would be extremely grateful for any advice, experiences, or thoughts you could share that might help me make an informed decision. Thank you in advance for your time and insights!

**P.S. - I'm looking to relocate to the US for better salary opportunities within the same technical field. Down the line, I intend to pursue an MBA to facilitate a transition into a managerial role.**

title: Google Bangalore [SSE L5 offer]
content:
Experience: 6 years 9 months
College: Tier 3 college from Thane (Graduated in 2017 with 2nd year failed). Completed B.E. in 5 years.

**Previous company**: Atlassian
**Previous base salary**: 41 LPA
**Target Bonus**: 15% of base = 6.15 lakh pro-rated
**RSU**: 300 rsu vested over 4 years (81 rsu for the 1st year at 206 usd/RSU) ~~ INR 13.83 lakh as of 4 Mar 2024. Vesting happens every quarter from day 1.
**Total**: 41+6.15+13.83 = 60.98 lakhs for 2024
**Current tech stack**: Java Spring, Nodejs, Postgres, kafka, redis, mongo

**Google offer:**
**Base**: 65 LPA (Was initially offered 54.5 LPA. I negotiated. But the reduced stocks)
**Target Bonus**: 15% of base = 9.75 lakh pro-rated
**RSU**: Worth $211000 (which was $241000 before negotiation) as of 4 Mar 2024 (Vesting: 38%, 32%, 20%, 10%) = $80180 for 1st year ~~ INR 66.46 Lakh as of March 2024. I am told vesting happens every single month since day 1. But not sure yet. Please do your own research.
**Total**: 1.41cr for 2024
**Total raise**: Almost 2.31x
**Expected tech stack**: I was asked to learn Python

**PS**: I have failed Google interview thrice previously for L4 role. Cleared in my 4th attempt, but this time for L5 role. ;)
Hence, "3 attempts max" is a myth. I can confirm.
**PSS**: I have my own reasons to reduce stocks and increase base salary. May not suit everyones needs.

**Interview experience**: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/4820834/Google-L5-SSE-interview-experience
**Offer accepted!**

title: Seeking Advice on Salary Expectations for SDE 3 Position at Amazon, Dublin
content:
Hello, LeetCode community!

I'm currently in the process of interviewing for a Software Development Engineer III (SDE 3) position at Amazon in Dublin, and I'm trying to gather some insights into what would be a reasonable salary expectation for this role, especially in comparison to the US standards.

From what I've gathered, the total compensation package for an SDE 3 at Amazon in the US seems to hover around the $500k mark annually, including base salary, RSUs (Restricted Stock Units), and bonuses. However, I'm finding it challenging to find equivalent information for the Dublin market. The lack of clear data has left me pondering on how to approach my salary negotiation effectively.

I'm aware that a direct comparison might not be straightforward. Nonetheless, I'm reaching out to see if anyone here has gone through a similar process or has insights into the tech industry and compensation trends in Dublin, especially for a company like Amazon.

Questions:

Does anyone have specific numbers or ranges for an SDE 3 role at Amazon in Dublin, including base salary, RSUs, and bonuses?
Are there any Dublin-based tech salary surveys or compensation benchmarks that you found helpful or reliable?
For those who have negotiated tech salaries in Dublin, any tips on what components of the compensation package are most flexible or negotiable?
I'm trying to set realistic expectations and prepare for my negotiation phase. Any advice, insights, or resources you could share would be immensely appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your help!

I am presently employed at a FAANG company with a cumulative experience of 3 years. Currently, my base salary stands at approximately 44 lakhs per annum. title: Cleartrip Interview
content:
The interview was for SDE 2.
There were a total of 4 rounds ( 3 Technical + 1 Hiring Manager)

Round 1 -> Technical -> Machine Coding (2.5 hrs)
		Conference room booking. Using Java. Apply all the necessary OOPs concepts. The code must accurately handle overlapping bookings and reject if the room is booed for the time slot.
		Went good. 
		
Round 2 -> Technical -> DSA (1 hr)
		Kadane's algorithm, BST problem ( similar to least common ancestor).
		went good.
		
Round 3 -> Technical -> System Design (1hr)
		Twitter System design. 
		1. follow other users
		2. make a post
		3. like/unlike a post
		4. comment on a post
		5. reply to comments
		6. trending posts based on likes

Round 4 -> Hiring Manager (30min)
		Basic discussion about my background and the technologies I know, mostly based on my resume.
		
Offer received -> 27LPA fixed + 10% variable + ESOPs

title: Compensation - Am I undervalued ?
content:
Hi Leetcoders , I have been working in a product company called Epsilon for the past 2 year 7months as a full stack developer. My current salary is 15.X Lakhs(started off with 10LPA)  . I have graduated in 2021 from a tier 2 college in bangalore . I have a very good knowledge in nodejs and angular , i think my company is underpaying me coz everytime i talk to my friends , I get to hear that you should have got more , you are being paid very less . I'm in so much dilemma of the pay , when i talk to manager , i get to hear that it is industry standard and a very good pay .

 Please share your thoughts i have been beating my head around this since many days . I received few offers around 18-20LPA from early stage startups but i find it so risky to leave a well settled company like epsilon for startups .

title: People, beware of KOTAK MAHINDRA
content:
I interviewed for SDE2 role, cleared all rounds.
The HR sent me congratulatory mail and asked for documents and expectations. I sent them and told about the expectation. He proposed initial figure and assured me he'll try for my expectation. He took more than a week and on my call he said they aren't moving forward with your profile. 
The reason he stated I have many switches in the past. I was just bewildered like WTF is this. I asked him if this was the case why did he interview me in the first place wasting time and metally draining. Also he verbally told me that I have cleared the interview and sent me the congratulatory mail and then this. 
They are completely unprofessional, pathetic and cheap.

#rant_over

title: Kotak mahindra Bank Interview Experience +  Offer Discussion
content:
I have recently interview with kotak for SDE-2 position

Prior Experience : 2.6 + 

Interview Experience : 
There were 3 rounds in total

First Round : Taken by Barraiser 
This round was of around 2 hrs there was one dsa question(Medium) , low level design of ecommerce + db design and questions related to distributed systems

Second Round : This was focued on data structures only 1 dsa question asked it was of medium difficulty and then asked to refactor the code using oops concepts

Third Round : Design a notification system + lld of one of the component and db design also to design all the apis.

Got the mail that i have cleared their interview but its been more than 10 days recruiter is not discussing the compensation, is there anyone else facing same or  it is the standard time they take in kotak to discuss the offer.


update : I have received the offer letter after more than a month, this is the standard time that they take, checked with some folks who got the offer.

title: Accenture Advanced App Engineering Analyst Thapar 2022
content:
**Accenture visited Thapar University Patiala in 2022 for the Advanced Application Engineering Analyst role**

Eligibility criteria included a BTech degree with a CGPA greater than 6.5. They selected a substantial number of candidates, totaling 42 individuals, including those from non-computer science backgrounds.

**The recruitment process comprised four rounds:**
* Three rounds of Online Assessment (OA).
* A final HR round.

1. The first OA round comprised six sections focusing on computer fundamental aptitude.
1. The second round included two coding questions, one at an easy level and the other at a medium level. 
1. The third round evaluated English communication skills, writting skills, reading and understanding comprehensions.
1. Fourth round was an Resume/Projects Grill + HR interview lasting 45 minutes.

The online test was conducted via the Metal platform and comprised **90 multiple-choice questions** across six sections, including English ability, critical reasoning and problem-solving, abstract reasoning, common applications, MS Office, pseudo code, networking security, and cloud. The overall difficulty level of the questions ranged from medium to hard.

Joining locations offered included Bangalore, Hyderabad, Gurgaon, and Pune. Initially, candidates were given the option to choose their preferred work location, but later, more than 60% were assigned to other locations not of their preference. The offer letters were issued late, on August 31st, with the first joining date set for September 26, 2023. The hiring process occurred in three phases: September 26th, October 15th, and November 24th.

**The compensation package offered a Total CTC of 12.59 LPA, comprising:**

**Base Salary: 9 LPA**
**Variable Pay: 1.89 LPA**
**Joining Bonus: 1 LPA**
**Gratuity and Insurance: 70k**

**Additional benefits not included in the CTC were monthly Wi-Fi reimbursement, a one-time reimbursement of 18k for WFH setup, an extra 20k for relocation assistance, and monthly outings and events.The Salary would be credited 2nd last day of every month.**

title: How to prepare a resume for internships for college students?
content:
Resume shortlisting is one of the most important steps in the application process. We often face many resume shortlisting rejections that discourage us a lot. Even if we are so talented and experienced, still we are facing rejections. I am going to mention the resume preparation techniques which could help you a lot:
1. First of all find a good resume template. Don`t go for the tabulated templates rather prefer single columns as they take care of the brevity of our resume.
2. Try to add numbers to precisely describe your work and achievements.
3. Don`t miss any heading like experiences, achievements, skills, etc, for example. If you haven`t enough experience try to mention your college positions like programming mentor etc.
4. Try to use the same date format in the entire resume.
5. While mentioning bullets or key points make sure to have a proper order,  alphabetical sequencing, etc.

title: Paypal SDE3 Bangalore || Disappointing experience
content:
Background: 10 years of experience as backend engg in product.
B.tech from Tier 2 college.

I had interview scheduled with Paypal last week and the first round was a general project discussion with the HM. He asked me in detail about my project work and then some typical scaling and design questions. He then asked a few behavioural questions. It was more of a fitment round. It went well and interviewer was very friendly.
I had then another 4 rounds of interview in a single day which was too overwhelming for me so I asked if it can be broken into two days. 
I had 2 rounds of interview on one day and another 2 rounds for the next day. 
1st Technical round: Interviewer gave a piece of code and asked to review and suggest if it can be better. It was about reading a csv file and writing into a db tables. We had a very detailed discussion which went for 1.5 hours and interviewer seemed satisfied. I would say, I couldn't answer all the questions but majority of them. Morever it was a very open ended interview with plethora of ways to answer it and I did well.
2nd Round: This interviewer just copy pasted a question of DP which unfortunately I had never attempted before. He didn't want to discuss much on this and simply wanted an answer. I tried to give a solution which was not optimal but then decided to write a code anyway. No suggestions from his side other than one which was absolutely wrong.
When I was left with 20 mins, he asked to leave that problem and copy pasted another matrix multiplication of diagonals sum problem. I saw it and quickly wrote a working code in 5 mins. He tried to find error in my code but couldn't. I then tried to rewrite the first problem but he seemed to have already made up his mind of rejecting which I could sense. So I couldn't finish it up. 

Got mail of disqualification from HR.  - _-
I am currently giving interviews in many companies but in one or the other round getting rejected. I don't know how much preparation is enough. For instance, I am trying to work on as many DP problems as I can but this one problem I just missed and wasted my chance.
How do you guys prepare and getting job offers?
What is the best way to approach questions which are medium/hard and you have never encountered them?

I am sick of getting rejected now and very disappointed in myself. Seems like living in an altogether different world post pandemic where every company has very very high expectations from the interviewee.

title: WALMART | ORACLE (CERNER)
content:
I have to make a quick decision and I am really confused between these 2 offers. Suggestions regaring team, work life balance, and culture would be appreciated.

Profile: iOS Developer | Exp 4 years | Tier 3 college | Native of Delhi NCR
Current Comp: 25.1 LPA (22.5 Fixed + 2.6 yearly bonus) Fintech Startup

Had 4 offers (Rejected 2 of them) Mentioning the remaning 2 here.

Offer 1: WALMART, Bangalore
Base: 29.6L
Yearly Bonus: 5.5L
RSUs: 7L (over 3 years) 2.3L per year
Joining Bonus: 3L
Total Comp: 37.4 LPA + 3L joining bonus = 40.4 LPA

They are asking to relocate to bangalore, and have hybrid 2 days/week office. Relocation is very expensive and I have to take care of that.
Standard Walmart Benefits are there. Gym membership, free food.

Offer 2: ORACLE (for Cerner field), Permanent **Work from home**
Base: 36 LPA
RSUs: 24L (over 4 years) 6L per year
Joining Bonus: 5L
Total Comp: 42 LPA + 5L joining bonus = 47 LPA

Pros: Permanent WFH is a huge thing, from monetary point of view as well. 
Cons: (Now this is bothering me) (Would appreciate answers to these questions)

1. Is Oracle Cerner's brand value as good as Oracle, and is it better than Walmart?
2. (Only iOS devs can answer this) Walmart is offering core iOS profile (which is my competancy) but Oracle has a mix of cross platform (they are using **Cordova** for it) I have no idea about **Cordova** as such.


I shall really appreciate any suggestions for the same. 
I will share the interview experience for both of them at the earliest.

Annual Bonus: NA

Stocks: NA
CTC: around 20.50 lakh

Rejected this offer immediately as less than expected. HR called after 4 days and agreed to match 20 lakh base, but I already had another offer of 20 lakh base in pipeline. After two days HR asked for the offer letter of 20 lakh I received from other company, without which they wont be able to match the base salary. Strange! Again, I rejected this request and mailed the HR to opt out from interview process. After 2 days got call from HR, they agreed to match expectations even without sharing competing offer.

New offer as per telephonic discussion:
Base: 20 lakh
Joining bonus: 2 lakh
CTC: around 23 lakh

Received many calls and texts in these 2 weeks even after rejecting offer multiple times. Literally felt like bargaining in fish market. I was very frustrated with this negotiation. I was really planning to join if HR had matched expected salary in beginning of discussion. But I am not a fan of this type of culture, so decided to move ahead with another company.

title: 🚀💻 Active WhatsApp group for Frontend Devs: Join the Community for Collaborative Growth! 🌟👨‍💻
content:
Hello Fellow Frontend Enthusiasts! 🌟💻🚀

I'm excited to share that I've created a dedicated WhatsApp community for Frontend Developers like us—a place where we can dive deep into the world of frontend development together. Whether you're a seasoned expert or just starting your journey, this group is for you!

***👩‍💻 Why Join Us?***

✨ Share Interview Experiences: Navigate the interview process with insights and tips from peers who've been in the trenches.

🚀 Job Opportunities: Be the first to know about exciting job openings. Share leads and opportunities within our circle.

🤝 Referrals and Job leads: Our community thrives on collaboration, opening new doors for each other. Together, we share opportunities and referrals, making the job market more navigable and helping everyone advance their careers.

💼 Professional Networking: Connect with fellow frontend developers, expanding your network for collaboration, sharing insights, and uncovering opportunities in our field.

🤝 Community Support: Find answers, get feedback, and engage with a supportive network of like-minded individuals.

🔍 Continuous Learning: Access a wealth of resources, workshops, and live discussions aimed at sharpening your skills.

🔮 Latest Frontend Tech: Immerse yourself in discussions about HTML, CSS, JavaScript, TypeScript, React.js, Next.js, and beyond. Whether it's decoding the mysteries of React hooks or exploring the depths of Next.js, we've got it all.

🏗️ System Design: Dive into the architectural essence of frontend development. Share strategies and learn how to construct scalable and maintainable systems.

🌈 And So Much More... Dive deeper into a plethora of frontend topics including advanced JavaScript frameworks, progressive web apps (PWAs), static site generators, SEO best practices, accessibility standards, and performance optimization. Our discussions are as limitless as our collective curiosity!

🚀 How to Join?

No need to wait or ask for permission! Click the link below to step into a world where code meets creativity, and let's push the boundaries of what we can build on the web together.

Join our Frontend WhatsApp Group: [Click Here or Copy and Paste this URL into Your Browser and join](https://chat.whatsapp.com/Btwz9fLuh3M18Wjl2ebm16)

Looking forward to seeing you on the other side, where we make frontend development not just a skill, but a craft. Let's learn, share, and grow together in our journey to frontend mastery!

Happy Coding! 🎉

**Last, but importantly, please consider upvoting this post to help spread the word about this group and ensure it reaches the right audience! Thank you!**

title: Frontend Internship at Atomic Loops
content:
After applying directly to their email upon discovering job openings through LinkedIn, I received a call from their HR department. They added me to a Slack channel and scheduled an interview. During the interview, I answered basic questions related to Git and GitHub and successfully resolved a merge conflict. Subsequently, I was assigned to create a basic project using React and Redux. Following the project completion, I underwent another interview where they asked detailed questions about the project.

Following these interviews, I received an email from HR informing me that I had been selected for the position. Additionally, I was offered a stipend of 5K every month.


There I contributed to the development of a responsive admin panel for an application using React and Redux. Additionally, I played a role in integrating Redux, which enhanced state management within the application. I collaborated with team members using version control systems such as Git to organize modifications and assign tasks. Moreover, I implemented ReCaptcha integration in a project to enhance security and prevent unauthorized access, thereby contributing to a more secure and reliable application.

title: Nvidia Campus Placement 2024 - Test Development Intern
content:
Requirements:
* Specialization in AI/ML with strong academics.
* Languages - C++/C#.Net/Python.
* Strong in OOPs concepts and Data structures.
* Knowledge of SQL/NoSQL Database management tools.

CTC: 15-20 lacs/Year
Stipend: 40,000 per month

**Interview Questions:**
* What is the difference between normalization and standardization?
* Various techniques to handle null values in the dataset?
* What will happen if all the weights in neural network are assigned same?
* What are various terminologies related to CNN?
* Define activation function. Briefly explain any three that you know.
* Regularization.
* What is gradient descent?
* Explain the problem of vanishing gradient descent.

(Questions were mainly from machine learning domain)

**Coding Questions**
* Find all the prime numbers in the range 1-n.
* Reverse a string without reversing the words. ("I am anonymous" -> "anonymous am I")
* Valid Parentheses.
* Delete the nth node from the end in the linked list.

**Tips for the interview:**
* Thorougly go through all the projects of yours (aiml projects were expected to have.)
* If you have created any application for your project, learn the system design of your application.

I cannot share further details.

Best of luck!

title: Tips and Resources for Effective LeetCode Preparation
content:
**Introduction:**
Greetings fellow coders! 👋 I wanted to share some valuable tips and resources to help you in your LeetCode preparation journey. Whether you're gearing up for coding interviews or just looking to sharpen your problem-solving skills, these insights can make your preparation more effective.

**Tips for LeetCode Preparation:**

	1. Understand the Basics:
		Ensure a solid grasp of data structures and algorithms.
		Focus on key concepts like arrays, linked lists, trees, graphs, sorting, and searching.  

	2. Start with Easy Problems:
		Begin with easy-level problems to build a strong foundation.
		Emphasize understanding the problem-solving process over speed initially.

	3. Grasp Time and Space Complexity:
		Analyze the time and space complexity of your code.
		Optimize solutions for efficiency.

	4. Explore Different Topics:
		Cover a range of topics, including dynamic programming, greedy algorithms, and backtracking.
		Prepare for a diverse set of problems.

	5. Consistent Practice:
		Regular practice is essential for mastering algorithmic problem-solving.
		Consistency is key.

Benefits: Everyone mentions 'standard google benefits', but I didnt know what they were, so mentioning some here
 - free breakfast, lunch and dinner
 - massage, gym and transport services
 - internet reimbursements, educational programs
 - my favourite : survivor benefit for spouse and children (3 times base)
 - peer bonus, spot bonus
 - Insurance : 
	 - medical insurance upto 5 dependents
	 - life insurance is 7 times base + 1 time target bonus
	 - accidental insurance 4 times base + 1 time target bonus
	 - critical insurance 2 times base 

Other details : There are multiple comments on similar compensation posts claiming they are fake - not sure if they are commenting to keep away potential candidates. FYI, I know couple of my connections getting similar compensation.

title: VP ||  EVP ||  DIRECTOR || SR.DIRECTOR || GOBAL HEAD  ||  AVP || ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR
content:
Narsimha Rao Mannepalli, EVP and co-head of Delivery, Infosys, resigned last year and is reportedly joining Cognizant. His remuneration grew from Rs 3.4 crore to Rs 6.6 crore.


Roy, who resigned from Infosys last month and hasn’t revealed his future plan, earned around Rs 5.1 crore, which jumped to Rs 10.6 crore from FY20 to FY23. Similarly, Dalal, who is now defending a suit from Wipro, saw his remuneration going up from Rs 4.4 crore to Rs 8.9 crore during the same period. Lobo, who joined Tech Mahindra as its chief people officer this month, drew about Rs 2.5 crore in FY20, which increased to Rs 4.9 crore in FY23.


Gopalkrishnan Konnanath, former senior vice president and global head – engineering services and blockchain, Infosys, who joined Cybage Software as its president last year – also saw his salary jump from Rs 1.5 crore to Rs 2.9 crore in the same period.

Hari Raja S, former global salesforce practice head at Wipro, who joined as partner at Ernst & Young in August 2023, saw his salary grow by 65% from Rs 2 crore to Rs 3.3 crore in two years and become one of the top 10 employees in terms of salary drawn in FY23.

Even notable executives who were promoted recently, like Jayesh Sanghrajka as the CFO of Infosys, Aparna Iyer, CFO, Wipro and Shaji Mathew as executive VP and group head, human resources, Infosys, saw jump in their remuneration — doubling or trebling.

Sanghrajka saw his remuneration more than double from `3.3 crore to `8.5 crore in the same period. Iyer’s remuneration grew from `1.1 crore in FY20 to more than `2 crore in FY23. Mathew, whose remuneration was Rs 2.2 crore in FY20, drew more than `4 crore in FY23.

While Infosys had more than 120 senior employees posted in India who earned more than Rs 1.02 crore per annum in FY23, the number for Wipro was around 65.




Jayadev Galla, CMD of Amara Raja Batteries, took home over Rs 52 crore as compensation in FY23. That was about 1,872 times the median salary of the company's employees. Amara Raja Batteries heads the list of top 10 companies with the widest gap between CEO pay and median employee remuneration.


https://www.financialexpress.com/business/industry-pay-cheques-for-senior-it-staff-doubled-in-last-three-years-3377168/

Other details:
* Negotiated a bit to get these numbers. Initial one was ~10% less
* Outstanding performers are also eligible for additional equity grants. Those are very lucrative but only 20-30% of employees manage to get it.
* Stock are not liquid. First vest takes 1y and will have to probably wait an additional year for buybacks, keep this in mind.

More Details:
* Stripe is pretty small in India. To prevent doxxing myself, I will not be sharing interview experience or benefits details
* To succeed in interview you need to have hands on expeirnece with REST APIs and day to day coding & debugging as the rounds are very practical based.
* DSA is asked but there is no focus on time/space complexity, instead it's on readability and structure.

title: Pre-seed startup vs Series B startup
content:
YOE: 4+
Current TC: 38L base + 2L bonus + 7k USD ESOPS(over 4 years)
Was laid off from the above company and started looking out. Got the below two offers.

Offer1: pre-seed startup
ESOPs : 0.1% equity over 4 years(2.5L/year, initial funding is 1million, so any further funding rounds will multiply current ESOP amount.)
Base : 40LPA
Work from office. So, will have to spend from pocket.

Offer2: Series B startup
ESOPs : 30K USD given over 4 years(these will have to be bought first by spending after-tax money)
Base : 44LPA(no other components)
Work from home. Will be saving 4+LPA by working from my hometown.

Any help on how to evaluate these will be very helpful. I'm basically unable to decide as the pre-seed startup offers a higher growth curve with lower compensation. But, the series-B startup offer is good in-terms of compensation but the stocks have to be bought first in order to be able to sell them.

title: Google India L6 vs. Current Facebook Role - Compensation and Location Considerations"
content:
Hi Everyone,

I recently received a job offer from Google India, and I'd appreciate some insights into whether the offer aligns with the company's standards. Here are the details:

Base Pay: 50 Lakhs
Joining Bonus: 8 Lakhs
Performance Bonus: 0-25%
RSU: 120 Lakhs vested over 4 years
I have a few questions and would be grateful for any guidance:

Does the offer meet Google India's compensation standards?

Regarding the performance bonus, is it calculated as a percentage of the base pay (50 lakhs)?

Initially, my job application mentioned a role of L5 and a location in Bengaluru. However, the offer letter states the role as L6 and the location as Gurgaon. Upon discussing this with the recruiter, I was informed that due to my substantial current CTC, they upgraded the role and changed the location. I expressed a preference for Bengaluru due to personal reasons, and the recruiter mentioned she would discuss it with the hiring manager. However, she indicated that chances of changing the location are slim, and even if it happens, there won't be any joining bonus. What should be my approach in this situation?

My total years of experience are 8, and my current CTC at Facebook is as follows:

Base Pay: 48 lakhs
Joining Bonus: 10 lakhs
RSU: 350 stocks
I'd appreciate any advice or insights you can provide. Thanks!

* Education: 2016 B.Tech Graduate, Tier 3 College
* Years of Experience: 7
* Prior Experience:

	* Title/Level: SDE 2
	* Location: Hyderabad

* Stock bonus: 140000 USD
* Variable Bonus(Incentive): 0-30% of Base
* Total comp (Salary + Bonus + Stock): 4500000(base)+300000(signing bonus)+2800000(stocks)+675000(variable bonus considering 15% of base) => **82,750,00**
* Benefits: Microsoft India Benefits

________________________________________________________________________
Hi Folks,

Today I received the offer from Microsoft India for L63 where-
1. Base Pay is 45 Lakhs
2. Joining Bonus is 7 Lakhs
3. Performance bonus is 0-30%
4. RSU is 112 Lakhs vested over 4 years

Could someone please answer my below queries-
1. Is the offer matches with Microsoft India standards?

2. Performance bonus is 0-30% of base pay(45 lakhs) or what?

3. In my job application the Job role was L62 and location was Noida but in the offer letter the role changed to L63 and location changed to Hyderabad. After this I checked with my recruiter where she mentioned that since my current CTC is high to match so they have upgraded the job role from L62 to L63 and the location from Noida to Hyderabad. However I insisted to join Noida location only as it would be my home location too. To this she mentioned that she will talk to the hiring manager regarding this but there are very less chances to change the job location and even if it is changes then  there wouldn’t be any joining bonus.

So what should I do?

My YOE - 7

My Current CTC at Amazon-
Base pay is 44 lakhs
Joining bonus is 12 lakhs
RSU 380 stocks

Previous discussion post -https://leetcode.com/discuss/career/4441415/Microsoft-AA-interview

**NOTE: Please dont down vote this post. I'll update this as per the format once the things are finalized.**

title: TCS Digital Interview Experience | On-Campus 2023 (Virtual) & salary breakdown
content:
There were 2 rounds for us 1st was OA(Aptitude+Coding) which was conducted on TCS-ION browser and next was Interview(TR, MR, HR) It is Digital so they require you to know Digital Technologies Search about them you will get to know them.

**Online Assessment**: This was first round which was divided into 3 sections also you cannot switch between sections. Also, there was sectional cutoff(One of my friend was not shortlisted for interview just because he was not able to solve many of verbal questions even though he had solved both coding questions).

Verbal- Believe me this was the toughest as it had only 10 minutes for 15 questions be fast in this round.
Aptitude- You will have enough time in this round i.e 35-40 min for 15 questions level of difficulty was easy-medium (check in pdf below).
**Coding Round**- This round had different experience for all as the exam was in batches, some had got very easy basic problem while some had got  DP based questions. also very important note TCS compiler is worst it might not work in last 5-10 minutes so try to complete and compile your code as early as possible.

**Interview**(TR, MR, HR): After OA results were declared after 1 week and I was shortlisted for an interview. It was on webex platform.  It was just one interview which had 3 interviewees TR, MR, HR which lasted for 30-40 minutes.

They took turns to ask questions Digital mainly requires DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES like ML, AI, etc. It is good if have a project in at least one and have basic knowledge about all . Many of my friends were asked questions on project/oops/ML like those who had projects in ML were asked in-depth about it.
NOTE the following pdf consist of all Question for 2022 batch for interview round(Guys this jackpot for you believe me 50 interview experience of my batchmate):
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1396SQGzhO5FY8sy4i3uD-02ytHE0qJoi/view?usp=sharing
But I had a different experience.
I introduced myself and then first TR asked technical questions he told me not to explain the project and directly asked me my preferred programming language which I said JAVA and then started asking me questions on JAVA, OOPS. Like what is an abstraction, what is the difference between abstract class and interface, and many standard java questions(GOOGLE TOP JAVA INTERVIEW QUESTIONS AND YOU WILL GET MOST OF THEM)?

**SALARY**
7lpa for digital candidates 
9lpa for innovators bachelors(iits and nits and iiits)
11.5lpa for innovators masters(iits and nits and iiits)

title: Offer Comparisons Wayfair Vs Google
content:
YOE: 2.5+ 
Education - BTech from Tier 1

Current Comp: 30.8 LPA (includes PF) + Bonus (which is not fixed)
Company: Top MNC (Fintech)
Title/Level: SDE2

Offer 1:
Company: Google
Title/Level: SDE1 (Down leveled)
Base: 26 LPA 
Perf Bonus: 3.9 LPA (15%)
Bonus: 5 Joining + 1.7 Relocation Bonus (Both has to be returned on prorated basis if left within 12 months)
Stocks: 51K USD
Benefits: 3.6 LPA (PF + Medical benefits + Google standard)
CTC: 55.7 LPA


Offer 2:
Company: Wayfair
Title/Level: SDE - L2
Salary: 40 LPA
Relocation/Signing Bonus: N/A
Stock: N/A
Bonus: N/A
Total comp (Salary + Bonus + Stock): INR 40 LPA
Benefits: N/A

Need some advice about which company should I go for? Please suggest based on Growth > Work Culture > WLB considering level offered + comp .

Going for google means waiting for 1.5 years on average for the promotion and won't have any hike unless promoted since this comp is already max out. Cannot leave mid way after joining Google because that would mean returning Signing + Relocation Bonus and not getting any stocks and base is already less than what I am getting currently.

Wayfair is fairly new in India? How is the growth, work, WLB, work culture?

Also, expecting offer from Cohesity. How is the company, work and WLB there? What comp can be expected from Cohesity?

Please let me know if there are any other suggestions.

Update: Recruiters reached out in case of both the companies.

title: Fidelity Investments - Data Engineer | Fresher
content:
Company Name : Fidelity Investments 
( holds largest Asset Under Management amount worth ~4x India's GDP )
Batch : 2019-2023
Role: Associate Data Engineer 

Salary Structure:
Base - 10.5 lpa
Bonus - 1.5 lpa
Other Allowances -
20k (wfh)
80k (relocation bonus)

Stocks:
Internal Share worth 3 Lakhs (automatically gets encashed after 1.5 years)

Total CTC :
16 LPA

Other Perks :

1.5 Months of Hotel Stay (5 star hotel of Bangalore and Chennai)
Profit Sharing (not fixed)
Free Food (tea,snacks and one meal a day , other meals are at cheaper rate  <$1)
Free Cab Service
( 7 different timings available for both login and logout )

Quality Food Items at Vending Machine (Cavin's Milkshake ,Protein Bars, fruit juice,soya chips etc)

NPS Matching (matches 5% of your NPS contribution amount)

Health Insurance 

Day Care facility 


Pros :
- Never laid of full time workers so job security is the biggest pro.
- Amazing work culture
- Beautiful office and flexible working hours
- 2 weeks wfh policy in a month
- They adopt newer tech stacks faster than any other Fintech firm
- Flexible team change option which can help one never feel bore about their current work and get to face newer challenges 
- Support from senior and special backing of LEAP (new college joinees ) \xA0from upper management.
- 3 Months of training where they bring international coaches and collaborate with other companies to give practical knowledge along with theoretical learnings

Cons:

- Lesser Pay when compared to other Fintech


Final Verdict:
Great company to work in if you aren't too ambitious and happy with your life but not a good company for those who are hustlers because the comfort you get here brings down your willness as there's not much pressure to work and get over exhausted

title: Decoding DevOps: Essential Tags for Seamless Integration
content:
Linux Commands:

ls: List files and directories.
cd: Change the current working directory.
mkdir: Create a new directory.
cp: Copy files or directories.
mv: Move or rename files or directories.
rm: Remove files or directories.
grep: Search for a pattern in files.
chmod: Change file permissions.
Git Commands:

git clone: Clone a repository into a new directory.
git add: Add changes to the staging area.
git commit: Record changes to the repository.
git pull: Fetch changes from a remote repository.
git push: Push changes to a remote repository.
git branch: List, create, or delete branches.
Docker Commands:

docker pull: Pull an image or repository from a registry.
docker build: Build an image from a Dockerfile.
docker run: Run a command in a new container.
docker ps: List running containers.
docker exec: Run a command in a running container.
SQL Commands:

SELECT: Retrieve data from one or more tables.
INSERT: Add new records to a table.
UPDATE: Modify existing records in a table.
DELETE: Remove records from a table.
CREATE TABLE: Create a new table.
Python Commands:

print(): Display output.
len(): Determine the length of an object.
type(): Return the type of an object.
import: Import a module.
def: Define a function.

title: Optimization code in C++
content:
The code you provided is written in C++ and is used to modify the synchronization behavior between C++ streams (like cin and cout) and the standard input/output streams provided by the C Standard Library.

Let me break down each line for you:

ios_base::sync_with_stdio(false);: By default, C++ standard input/output streams (cin, cout, etc.) are synchronized with the C standard I/O streams (stdin, stdout, etc.). This means that operations on one set of streams affect the other. Disabling synchronization (sync_with_stdio(false)) can improve the performance of C++ input/output operations, as it eliminates the need for synchronization between C++ and C I/O.

cin.tie(NULL);: By default, the C++ input stream (cin) is tied to the C++ output stream (cout). This means that when you perform an input operation using cin, it automatically flushes the output buffer of cout. Setting cin.tie(NULL) unties cin from cout, which can improve the performance by avoiding unnecessary flushing.

cout.tie(NULL);: Similar to the previous line, this unties the C++ output stream (cout) from the C++ input stream (cin). This can also improve performance by avoiding unnecessary flushing.

These optimizations are often used in competitive programming or scenarios where performance is critical. In regular application development, especially for iOS development using Swift or Objective-C, you may not need to explicitly use these optimizations.

title: For beginner in JAVA
content:
* Learn the basics of Java syntax, data types, control flow (if statements, loops), and functions.
Understand the concept of classes and objects, as Java is an object-oriented language.
* Learn how to read input from the standard input (System.in) and print output to the standard output (System.out).
* Utilize the Scanner class for input and System.out.println for output.
* Learn how to read input from the standard input (System.in) and print output to the standard output (System.out).

title: Nutanix | MTS3
content:
Education: B.E in CSE (Tier 3 College)
Years of Experience: 3.5 years
Company: Nutanix
Title/Level: MTS3
Basic Salary: ₹ 34 LPA
Stock bonus: Worth $75K (Around ₹ 62.5L) vested over 4 years
Total comp (Salary + Bonus + Stock): ~ 49.5lpa
Other Benefits: Cab(Uber/Ola-7000 INR/month,Mobile/Internet - 3300 INR /Month)

Rejected the offer as I had a competing offer. 

Edit : Since a lot of you are asked me to share interview experience, here it goes.

1. Coding round 1 - LC Med (1 hour):
	* 	Given a BST and a value, split the tree into 2 subtrees, 1 with all values lesser than given value and the other with all values greater. Was able to get working code using DFS, interviewer followed up with questions on run time complexities.
	* 	Given a matrix, find the longest increasing subsequence. Was able to come up with a solution using DFS with caching, interviewer was happy with the solution.

2. Coding round 2 - LC Med (1 hour):
	*  Given a circular queue, return the next greater element for each element. Initially came up with a sliding window approach which the interviewer said wouldn't work (rightfully so). Was able to come up with an approach using monotonic stack which the interviewer said would work, only gave the psuedocode.
	*  Given a set of islands, return the number of groups of islands which are directly or indirectly connected to one another. Was able to come up with a DFS approach and got the code to work.

3. Design round (Senior staff engineer, 1 hour):
	* Was asked questions around my projects mentioned in resume for about 20-25 mins. Later we had a long discussion on API design patterns, microservice communication mechanisms, database replication and sharding strategies, high availability, health monitoring and logging infra etc. Overall it was a very nice interaction.

4. Design round (Chief architect, 1 hour):
	* 	Discussion on previous projects, couple of behaviour questions. Had a discussion on the high level design for a chat app and then was asked to code up some of the psuedocode for the same. Overall it was a fun round and didn't feel like an interview. 

5. HM round (1 hour):
	* Questions on previous work experience, projects and behavioural questions.


Competing offer was a remote job offer from a web3 startup in US for around  $150K (70K base, 80K ESOP). I chose to join them mainly because its a very small team and will be a great learning experience even if the stocks end up meaning nothing in the long run. Also, opportunity to move to US at some point in the future.
